title: Introduction to UnilSports package
text: optimize_schedule() allows evaluate calorie burn per activity time according parameters entered. main objective minimize number chosen activities. \[min\sum_{=1}^N x_i\] \(x_i\) binary variable 1 activity \(\) chosen 0 chosen. optimization function calculates calorie burn subject 3 constraints: total calorie burn must exceed target calorie: \[\sum_{=1}^N (x_i \cdot cal_i) \geq calburn\] \(cal_i\) calorie burn activity \(\) \(calburn\) target calorie. overlapping time slots: set constraints ensure one activity can selected overlapping time interval. example, activity starts 8.00 ends 9.00 activity B starts 8.45 ends 9.15, selected together (.e. one can selected). \[\sum_{\} x_i, \sum_{\B} x_i, \sum_{\C} x_i,... \leq 1\] overlapping time intervals \(\), \(B\), \(C\), … [Optional] Prohibiting selection duplicate activities: set constraints activity selected. example, several Football sessions, 1 Football session can selected. \[\sum_{\} x_i, \sum_{\J} x_i, \sum_{\K} x_i, ... \leq 1\] duplicate activities \(\), \(J\), \(K\), … duplicate activities activity \(\), \(J\), \(K\), … activity. understand significance parameter, use ?optimize_schedule() command console.

title: Introduction to UnilSports package
code: # Amount of calories you want to burn calburn <- 500  # Date preference - keep the same format* date <- c('2022-12-14')  # Sport activity of interest # The activity has to appear on the date selected activity <- c('Football / Pratique libre','Badminton / Tous niveaux',               'Aquagym', 'Zumba', 'Pilates', 'Agrès',                'Salsa cubaine / Débutants')  # Your current weight(kg) weight <- 50  # Time availability time <- c('07:00 \u2013 19:00')  # 1 if you want different activities, 0 otherwise flag_no_duplicate_activities <- 1  # Load the clean_sport_schedule from the package clean_sport_schedule <- UnilSports::clean_sport_schedule  # Apply optimize_schedule() function optimize_output <- optimize_schedule(clean_sport_schedule, date, activity,                                      time, calburn, weight,                                     flag_no_duplicate_activities) #> The optimization is successful # Call function and see the results head(optimize_output$table_result,10) #>          Date Start time End time time Duration_min                  Activity #> 1  2022-12-14          8        9    1           60 Football / Pratique libre #> 13 2022-12-14         11       12    1           60                   Pilates #>                                   Location METs    p calburn #> 1  Rugby-Foot Chamberonne 1/2 terrain nord    8 8.40   420.0 #> 13                   CSS-Salle polyvalente    3 3.15   157.5

title: Introduction to UnilSports package
text: pie_optim() let user print pie chart reflecting output optimization function. function use inside Shiny app function logic.

title: Introduction to UnilSports package
code: # Amount of calories you want to burn calburn <- 500  # Date preference - keep the same format* date <- c('2022-12-14')  # Sport activity of interest # The activity has to appear on the date selected activity <- c('Football / Pratique libre','Badminton / Tous niveaux',               'Aquagym', 'Zumba', 'Pilates', 'Agrès',                'Salsa cubaine / Débutants')  # Your current weight(kg) weight <- 50  # Time availability time <- c('07:00 \u2013 19:00')  # 1 if you want different activities, 0 otherwise flag_no_duplicate_activities <- 1  # Load the clean_sport_schedule from the package clean_sport_schedule <- UnilSports::clean_sport_schedule  # Run the function optimize_output <- optimize_schedule(clean_sport_schedule, date, activity,                                      time, calburn, weight,                                     flag_no_duplicate_activities) #> The optimization is successful optim_plot <- optimize_output$table_result  # Call function pie_optim(optim_plot)  #> [[1]] #>  #> [[2]]

text: aim package optimize selection UNIL/EPFL sports center activities depending characteristics needs individual. Given huge variety offered, activities shortly defined provide various information people interested amount calories burned, intensity activity. information useful people want follow detailed track physical activity. Therefore, project providing interactive dashboard suggests personal timetable different sports classes based user’s preference availability might facilitate class-search process. way easier UNIL/EPFL students introduce physical activity schedules motivated .

title: Create a Dashboard with Shiny Apps for sports schedules and calorie burn
text: package user able visualize dashboard daily exercise recommendation plan based user’s preference. obtain recommendation, users required fill information following: number calories users like burn per day. preferable time slot users like workout . Preferable sport activities. Similar preferable time slot, users can select multiple sport activities dropdown list classes provided. User’s weight. needed calculate number calories burned.

title: Create a Dashboard with Shiny Apps for sports schedules and calorie burn
text: order complete project, anticipate use following packages: rvest tidyverse lubridate lpSolve dplyr data.table rlang plotly shiny shinythemes bslib

title: Create a Dashboard with Shiny Apps for sports schedules and calorie burn
text: use data Sports Universitaires Lausanne create main table containing daily time table sport activity. Sports Universitaires Lausanne MET Values 800+ activities addition, use MET value data create another table containing two columns; list sport activities (matching activities Sports Universitaires Lausanne) number calories burned based formula Calculate Calories Burn Exercise. calculate number calories burned user, follow formula. Total calories burned = Duration (minutes) * (MET * 3.5 *weight  kg)/200 information MET can found Using Metabolic Equivalent Task (MET) Exercises.

title: Create a Dashboard with Shiny Apps for sports schedules and calorie burn
text: Objective function: minimize number chosen activities $$min\sum_{=1}^N x_i$$ xi binary variable 1 activity chosen 0 chosen. Constraints: total calorie burn must exceed target calorie: $$\sum_{=1}^N (x_i \cdot cal_i) \geq calburn$$ cali calorie burn activity calburn target calorie. overlapping time slots: set constraints ensure one activity can selected overlapping time interval. example, activity starts 8.00 ends 9.00 activity B starts 8.45 ends 9.15, selected together (.e. one can selected). ∑ ∈ Axi, ∑ ∈ Bxi, ∑ ∈ Cxi, ... ≤ 1 overlapping time intervals , B, C, … [Optional] Prohibiting selection duplicate activities: set constraints activity selected. example, several Football sessions, 1 Football session can selected. ∑ ∈ Ixi, ∑ ∈ Jxi, ∑ ∈ Kxi, ... ≤ 1 duplicate activities , J, K, … optimization algorithm unable find solution, indicates combination activities whose total calorie expenditure exceeds target calorie burn rate. case, optimizer returns combination activities results highest total calorie expenditure, rather minimum number activities. can achieved modifying objective function first constraint follows: Modified objective function: maximize total calorie burn $$\max \sum_{=1}^N (x_i \cdot cal_i)$$ xi binary variable 1 activity chosen 0 chosen, cali calorie burn activity . Modified first constraint: $$\sum_{=1}^N (x_i \cdot cal_i) \leq calburn$$

text: Arturo Garcia Luna Beltran Manunpat Sirijaturaporn Nadine Obeid Katti Irastorza

title: Server function for UnilSports Shiny Application — build_server
code: build_server(clean_sport_schedule) #> function (input, output, session)  #> { #>     observe({ #>         update_date <- input$date #>         update_schedule <- filter(clean_sport_schedule, Date ==  #>             update_date) #>         update_time <- input$time #>         if (!is.null(update_time)) { #>             update_schedule <- mutate(update_schedule, time = 0) #>             timetemp <- as.data.frame(matrix(as.numeric(gsub("\\:",  #>                 ".", unlist(strsplit(sort(update_time), "–")))),  #>                 ncol = 2, byrow = TRUE)) #>             n <- length(update_time) #>             selected_time <- data.frame() #>             for (i in 1:n) { #>                 if (i == 1) { #>                   output_temp <- timetemp[i, ] #>                 } #>                 else { #>                   output_temp2 <- timetemp[i, ] #>                   if (output_temp[2] == output_temp2[1]) { #>                     output_temp[2] <- output_temp2[2] #>                   } #>                   else { #>                     selected_time <- rbind(selected_time, output_temp) #>                     output_temp <- timetemp[i, ] #>                   } #>                 } #>                 if (i == n) { #>                   selected_time <- rbind(selected_time, output_temp) #>                 } #>             } #>             k <- nrow(selected_time) #>             for (j in 1:k) { #>                 update_schedule$time <- update_schedule$time |  #>                   (update_schedule$`Start time` >= selected_time[j,  #>                     1] & update_schedule$`End time` <= selected_time[j,  #>                     2]) #>                 update_schedule$time <- 1 * update_schedule$time #>             } #>             update_schedule <- update_schedule %>% filter(time ==  #>                 1) #>         } #>         update_activity <- unique(update_schedule)$Activity #>         updateSelectInput(session, "activity", choices = update_activity) #>     }) #>     optimize_output <- eventReactive(input$opt, { #>         outputtemp <- optimize_schedule(clean_sport_schedule,  #>             input$date, input$activity, input$time, input$calburn,  #>             input$weight, as.numeric(input$no_dup)) #>     }) #>     output$optim_table <- renderTable(hover = T, { #>         data.frame(optimize_output()[2]) %>% select(-c(table_result.Date,  #>             table_result.time, table_result.METs, table_result.p)) %>%  #>             rename(`Start Time` = table_result.Start.time, `End Time` = table_result.End.time,  #>                 `Duration (min)` = table_result.Duration_min,  #>                 Activity = table_result.Activity, Location = table_result.Location,  #>                 Calburn = table_result.calburn) #>     }) #>     output$optim_result <- renderText({ #>         if (optimize_output()[1] == 1) { #>             sprintf("The optimization is successful! Total Exercise Duration: %.0f min, Total Calorie Burn: %.0f",  #>                 optimize_output()[5], optimize_output()[4]) #>         } #>         else if (optimize_output()[1] == 2) { #>             sprintf("Cannot reach the calorie burn target. The optimizer returns the solution with the highest possible calorie burn. Total Exercise Duration: %.0f min, Total Calorie Burn: %.0f",  #>                 optimize_output()[5], optimize_output()[4]) #>         } #>         else { #>             sprintf(cat("No feasible solution found")) #>         } #>     }) #>     output$calburnplot <- renderPlotly({ #>         optim_plot <- optimize_output()$table_result #>         p <- pie_optim(optim_plot) #>         p[[1]] #>     }) #>     output$durationplot <- renderPlotly({ #>         optim_plot <- optimize_output()$table_result #>         p <- pie_optim(optim_plot) #>         p[[2]] #>     }) #>     output$activity_table <- renderTable({ #>         data.frame(optimize_output()[3]) %>% select(-c(activity_selected.Date,  #>             activity_selected.time, activity_selected.METs, activity_selected.p)) %>%  #>             rename(`Start Time` = activity_selected.Start.time,  #>                 `End Time` = activity_selected.End.time, `Duration (min)` = activity_selected.Duration_min,  #>                 Activity = activity_selected.Activity, Location = activity_selected.Location,  #>                 Calburn = activity_selected.calburn) #>     }) #>     output$image <- renderImage({ #>         list(src = "image.png", align = "right", height = "100%",  #>             width = "auto", deleteFile = FALSE) #>     }) #> } #> <bytecode: 0x56140f300ff8> #> <environment: 0x56140f2edb90>

title: Optimization Function — optimize_schedule
text: Function evaluates calorie burn per activity time according       parameters entered.       optimization function calculates calaory burn subject 3      constraints:      1. total calorie burn must exceed target calorie Equation: sum(x_i*cal_i) >= calburn cal_i calorie burn activity calburn target calorie.     2. overlapping time slots. optimizer select 2 activities occur time. example, activity starts 8.00 ends 9.00 activity B starts 8.45 ends 9.15, selected together (.e. one can selected) Equation: x_a + x_b + x_c +... <= 1 overlapping time intervals activity , b, c,... overlapping time slots.      3. select activity.activity selected. example, several Football sessions, 1 Football session can selected. Equation: x_i + x_j + x_k + ... <= 1 duplicate activities activity , j, k,... activity

title: Optimization Function — optimize_schedule
code: optimize_schedule(   clean_sport_schedule,   date,   activity,   time,   calburn,   weight,   flag_no_duplicate_activities = 0 )

title: Optimization Function — optimize_schedule
text: clean_sport_schedule data frame output  get_cleanschedule_met. output function  modified, function can apply integer optimization technique  properly. date date user wants search activities . activity type sports activity user wants attend. time timing user available . calburn minimum number calories user wants burn. weight actual weight kg user. flag_no_duplicate_activities decides whether show duplicates  output .  flag_no_duplicate_activities = TRUE,  duplicate activities output.

title: Optimization Function — optimize_schedule
text: returns list 5 items, optim_result, table_result.       details best activity/ies, activity_selected,       totalcal, totalduration.

title: Optimization Function — optimize_schedule
text: Arturo Garcia Luna Beltran Manunpat Sirijaturaporn Nadine Obeid Katti Irastorza

title: Optimization Function — optimize_schedule
code: library(UnilSports) calburn <- 500 date <- c('2022-12-14') activity <- c('Aquagym', 'Zumba', 'Pilates', 'Tai ji quan / Tous niveaux',              'Cirque') weight <- 50 time <- c('07:00 \u2013 08:00', '08:00 \u2013 09:00', '12:00 \u2013 13:00',      '13:00 \u2013 14:00', '17:00 \u2013 18:00', '18:00 \u2013 19:00',      '19:00 \u2013 20:00') flag_no_duplicate_activities <- 1 clean_sport_schedule <- UnilSports::clean_sport_schedule optimize_output <- optimize_schedule(clean_sport_schedule, date, activity,                                       time, calburn, weight,                                      flag_no_duplicate_activities) #> The target calorie burn can not be met

title: piechart Function — pie_optim
text: Arturo Garcia Luna Beltran Manunpat Sirijaturaporn Nadine Obeid Katti Irastorza

title: piechart Function — pie_optim
code: library(UnilSports) calburn <- 500 date <- c('2022-12-14') activity <- c('Aquagym', 'Zumba', 'Pilates',              'Tai ji quan / Tous niveaux',              'Cirque') weight <- 50 time <- c('07:00 \u2013 08:00', '08:00 \u2013 09:00', '12:00 \u2013 13:00', '13:00 \u2013 14:00',          '17:00 \u2013 18:00', '18:00 \u2013 19:00', '19:00 \u2013 20:00') flag_no_duplicate_activities <- 1 clean_sport_schedule <- UnilSports::clean_sport_schedule optimize_output <- optimize_schedule(clean_sport_schedule, date, activity,      time, calburn, weight,flag_no_duplicate_activities) #> The target calorie burn can not be met optim_plot <- optimize_output$table_result pie_optim(optim_plot) #call function #> [[1]] #>  #> [[2]] #>
